grammarNote.title: Relative Clauses
grammarNote.explanation: In Japanese, a modifying clause comes BEFORE the noun it describes (the opposite of English). Instead of 'the storm that came,' Japanese says きた嵐 (came-storm). Any verb phrase can modify a noun this way: 飛んだ帽子 (the hat that flew), 忘れたもの (the thing [I] forgot). There is no relative pronoun like 'that' or 'which' — the clause simply sits in front of the noun.

examples.japanese: 帽子 が 飛んだ！

vocabulary.example: これ は どんな 嵐？
もの が 飛ぶ ね。
前 に こんな もの は なかった。
